#Text=PLAERDEMAVIDA
#Text=By the great mercy of God , Plaerdemavida was saved from the shipwreck and taken to the city of Tunis , to the house of a fisherman 's daughter , as was related previously .
#Text=Then , after two years had passed the fisherman 's daughter took a husband near that city .
#Text=And while they held Plaerdemavida captive there , she always lived very honestly , working gold and silk as the maidens of Greece are accustomed to doing .
#Text=It happened one day that her mistress went to the city of Montagata , and left Plaerdemavida to watch the house .
#Text=She had gone to the city to make some purchases , and while she was there she went to talk to the king 's daughter , and she told her :
#Text=" My lady , I 've been told that you are planning to marry , and that you are supplying yourself with blouses embroidered with gold and silk and other things proper for maidens .

#Text=If you want her , I will give her to you for one hundred doubloons , even though I will be losing all the training I have given her .

_	_	_	_

#Text=The princess , seeing the samples , wanted her very much , and she said that she would be happy to give her the one hundred doubloons .

#Text= I 'll be glad to give her to you for that price , on one condition : you must tell her that I have loaned her to you for two months , because if she guessed that I had sold her , she would be so sad that she would fall into despair . "

column1: #Text=Plaerdemavida was placed in her hands and she came to love the princess very much .
#Text=It happened a short time later that the city was attacked , and the Moors took many Christians prisoner .
#Text=Among the men they captured was a soldier who had been an oarsman on Tirant 's galley when it was lost .
#Text=Plaerdemavida recognized him , and she said :
#Text=" Are n't you one of the Christians who were on Tirant 's galley when it went down at sea ? "
#Text=" My lady , " said the man " it 's true : I was there , and I nearly drowned .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= What can you tell me about Tirant ? " said Plaerdemavida .

column1: #Text=" Where did he die ? "
#Text=" By the Virgin Mary ! " said the prisoner .
#Text=" He is very much alive .
#Text=" That maiden you 're asking about , " said the prisoner , " it 's believed that she died in the sea , and our captain has grieved deeply over her . "
#Text=When she heard the news she ordered all the prisoners to flee .

#Text=Hearing that Tirant was alive and so near , she also wanted very much to escape , but considering how Tirant had conquered so much of the Barbary Coast , and thinking of the victories that were told about the Christian captain , she was very happy .
#Text=For she had known nothing about him and believed that he had drowned in the sea .

#Text=She fell to her knees , raised her clasped hands to heaven and gave thanks and praise to God Our Lord for the great success He had given to Tirant and to the new Christianity , for he was making war on the enemies of Jesus Christ so bravely .

#Text=She became very hopeful that soon she would be out of captivity , and all the suffering she had gone through up to then seemed to be nothing to her : the thought that she would see Tirant consoled her that much .
#Text=On the day her mistress had to go and talk to the captains , she disguised herself so well that no one would recognize her .
#Text=When the lady was before the captain , she was accompanied by fifty maidens , but Tirant would not listen to her and he sent her to his cousin , Lord Agramunt .
#Text=And if he had replied badly to the ambassadors , he gave an even worse reply to the lady .
#Text=Hopeless , they went back , crying and lamenting loudly .
#Text=All that night , men as well as women did not cease their wailing and sighing .

#Text=In the morning Plaerdemavida told her mistress and the honorable men of the city that if they would give her liberty to go out , she would talk to the captain , and would tell him such things that he would do anything she wished .
#Text=They agreed that she should go , because they had lost all hope and had only that one day left .
#Text=That day Plaerdemavida dressed as a Moor , and painted her eyes so that she would not be recognized .
#Text=She took thirty well dressed maidens with her .
#Text=At noon they left the city and went to the camp , and there they saw Tirant at the door of his tent .
#Text=When he saw them coming he sent word that they should go to Lord Agramunt , and that he could do nothing since he had turned all his power over to him .
#Text=Plaerdemavida answered :
#Text=" Tell the captain that he should not refuse to see us , and even less to speak to us , because if that captain did such a thing he would be cruel and unjust .
